sdg_targets.description: Support least developed countries, including through financial and technical assistance, in building sustainable and resilient buildings utilizing local materials

indicators.description: Total official development assistance and other official flows in support of urban infrastructure or urban infrastructure projects, by sector

sdg_targets.description: Implement the 10-Year Framework of Programmes on Sustainable Consumption and Production Patterns, all countries taking action, with developed countries taking the lead, taking into account the development and capabilities of developing countries

indicators.description: Number of countries developing, adopting or implementing policy instruments aimed at supporting the shift to sustainable consumption and production

sdg_targets.description: By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources

indicators.description: Material footprint, material footprint per capita, and material footprint per GDP
Domestic material consumption, domestic material consumption per capita, and domestic material consumption per GDP

practice_links.evidence: The overall goal of achieving sustainable management of resources aligns with reducing the GHG emissions intensity of extraction.
practice_links.math_model: Model linking GHG per ton of ore to sustainable resource management score.

practice_links.evidence: Practice Action 'Improve Water Use Efficiency' (ac22) is a key component of achieving sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.
practice_links.math_model: Model linking water withdrawal rates to overall natural resource accounting frameworks.

concern_links.evidence: Sustainable management of natural resources is the essence of responsible sourcing.
Sustainable resource management is a primary goal of ESG-focused investors.

sdg_targets.description: By 2030, halve per capita global food waste at the retail and consumer levels and reduce food losses along production and supply chains, including post-harvest losses

indicators.description: (a) Food loss index and (b) food waste index

sdg_targets.short_name: Environmentally Sound Management of Chemicals & Waste
sdg_targets.description: By 2020, achieve the environmentally sound management of chemicals and all wastes throughout their life cycle, in accordance with agreed international frameworks, and significantly reduce their release to air, water and soil in order to minimize their adverse impacts on human health and the environment

indicators.description: Number of parties to international multilateral environmental agreements on hazardous waste, and other chemicals that meet their commitments and obligations in transmitting information as required by each relevant agreement
(a) Hazardous waste generated per capita; and (b) proportion of hazardous waste treated, by type of treatment

practice_links.evidence: This practice directly supports the environmentally sound management of chemicals and all wastes to significantly reduce their release to air.
practice_links.math_model: Model tracking mass balance of chemicals and their release pathways.

practice_links.evidence: Managing effluents and water discharge is critical for the environmentally sound management of hazardous waste and chemicals to prevent their release to water.
practice_links.math_model: Model tracking mass balance of chemical releases into water bodies.

concern_links.evidence: Responsible management of chemicals and waste is a primary method for ensuring environmental health and safety.

sdg_targets.description: By 2030, substantially reduce waste generation through prevention, reduction, recycling and reuse

indicators.description: Number of companies publishing sustainability reports

indicators.description: Number of countries implementing sustainable public procurement policies and action plans

indicators.description: Extent to which (i) global citizenship education and (ii) education for sustainable development are mainstreamed in (a) national education policies; (b) curricula; (c) teacher education; and (d) student assessment

sdg_targets.description: Support developing countries to strengthen their scientific and technological capacity to move towards more sustainable patterns of consumption and production

sdg_targets.description: Rationalize inefficient fossil-fuel subsidies that encourage wasteful consumption by removing market distortions, in accordance with national circumstances, including by restructuring taxation and phasing out those harmful subsidies, where they exist, to reflect their environmental impacts, taking fully into account the specific needs and conditions of developing countries and minimizing the possible adverse impacts on their development in a manner that protects the poor and the affected communities

indicators.description: Amount of fossil-fuel subsidies (production and consumption) per unit of GDP

Proportion of local governments that adopt and implement local disaster risk reduction strategies in line with national disaster risk reduction strategies

Total greenhouse gas emissions per year

sdg_targets.description: Implement the commitment undertaken by developed-country parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change to a goal of mobilizing jointly $100 billion annually by 2020 from all sources to address the needs of developing countries in the context of meaningful mitigation actions and transparency on implementation and fully operationalize the Green Climate Fund through its capitalization as soon as possible

indicators.description: Amounts provided and mobilized in United States dollars per year in relation to the continued existing collective mobilization goal of the $100 billion commitment through to 2025

sdg_targets.short_name: Promote Climate Planning Mechanisms in LDCs
sdg_targets.description: Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities

indicators.description: Number of least developed countries and small island developing States with nationally determined contributions, long-term strategies, national adaptation plans and adaptation communications, as reported to the secretariat of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

sdg_targets.description: By 2025, prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution

practice_links.evidence: Managing effluents and preventing contaminated runoff directly helps reduce marine pollution from land-based activities.
practice_links.math_model: Hydrological model linking land-based runoff to coastal water pollution loads.

sdg_targets.description: By 2020, sustainably manage and protect marine and coastal ecosystems to avoid significant adverse impacts, including by strengthening their resilience, and take action for their restoration in order to achieve healthy and productive oceans

indicators.description: Number of countries using ecosystem-based approaches to managing marine areas

sdg_targets.description: Minimize and address the impacts of ocean acidification, including through enhanced scientific cooperation at all levels

indicators.description: Average marine acidity (pH) measured at agreed suite of representative sampling stations

practice_links.evidence: ocean acidification is directly driven by atmospheric CO₂; a core indicator of carbon uptake.
practice_links.math_model: Stoichiometric model of CO2 dissolution and ocean pH change.

practice_links.evidence: The release of Sulfur Oxides (SOx) and Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) are known precursors to acid rain, which is a major contributor to ocean acidification. Practice Action 'Implement Specialized Emission Controls' (ac14) directly addresses this.
practice_links.math_model: Atmospheric chemistry model linking SOx/NOx emissions to acid rain formation and subsequent ocean pH impact.

sdg_targets.description: By 2020, effectively regulate harvesting and end overfishing, illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and destructive fishing practices and implement science-based management plans, in order to restore fish stocks in the shortest time feasible, at least to levels that can produce maximum sustainable yield as determined by their biological characteristics

indicators.description: Proportion of fish stocks within biologically sustainable levels

sdg_targets.description: By 2020, conserve at least 10 per cent of coastal and marine areas, consistent with national and international law and based on the best available scientific information

indicators.description: Coverage of protected areas in relation to marine areas

sdg_targets.description: By 2020, prohibit certain forms of fisheries subsidies which contribute to overcapacity and overfishing, eliminate subsidies that contribute to illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and refrain from introducing new such subsidies, recognizing that appropriate and effective special and differential treatment for developing and least developed countries should be an integral part of the World Trade Organization fisheries subsidies negotiation3

indicators.description: Degree of implementation of international instruments aiming to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing

sdg_targets.short_name: Increase Economic Benefits from Marine Resources
sdg_targets.description: By 2030, increase the economic benefits to small island developing States and least developed countries from the sustainable use of marine resources, including through sustainable management of fisheries, aquaculture and tourism

indicators.description: Sustainable fisheries as a proportion of GDP in small island developing States, least developed countries and all countries

sdg_targets.description: Increase scientific knowledge, develop research capacity and transfer marine technology, taking into account the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission Criteria and Guidelines on the Transfer of Marine Technology, in order to improve ocean health and to enhance the contribution of marine biodiversity to the development of developing countries, in particular small island developing States and least developed countries

indicators.description: Proportion of total research budget allocated to research in the field of marine technology

sdg_targets.description: Provide access for small-scale artisanal fishers to marine resources and markets

indicators.description: Degree of application of a legal/regulatory/ policy/institutional framework which recognizes and protects access rights for small-scale fisheries

sdg_targets.description: Enhance the conservation and sustainable use of oceans and their resources by implementing international law as reflected in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, which provides the legal framework for the conservation and sustainable use of oceans and their resources, as recalled in paragraph 158 of “The future we want”

indicators.description: Number of countries making progress in ratifying, accepting and implementing through legal, policy and institutional frameworks, ocean-related instruments that implement international law, as reflected in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, for the conservation and sustainable use of the oceans and their resources, as recalled in paragraph 158 of “The future we want”

sdg_targets.description: By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements

Proportion of important sites for terrestrial and freshwater biodiversity that are covered by protected areas, by ecosystem type

practice_links.math_model: Model linking groundwater levels and surface water flows to ecosystem health.

concern_links.evidence: Protecting ecosystems is fundamental to maintaining environmental health.

sdg_targets.description: By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally

practice_links.math_model: Model linking water availability to soil moisture and vegetation cover.

sdg_targets.description: By 2030, ensure the conservation of mountain ecosystems, including their biodiversity, in order to enhance their capacity to provide benefits that are essential for sustainable development

(a) Mountain Green Cover Index and (b) proportion of degraded mountain land

practice_links.math_model: Model linking air pollutant concentrations to forest health indicators in mountain regions.

sdg_targets.description: Take urgent and significant action to reduce the degradation of natural habitats, halt the loss of biodiversity and, by 2020, protect and prevent the extinction of threatened species

indicators.description: Red List Index

concern_links.evidence: Protecting biodiversity is an integral part of ensuring ecosystem health and safety.

indicators.description: Proportion of traded wildlife that was poached or illicitly trafficked

sdg_targets.description: Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere

Conflict-related deaths per 100,000 population, by sex, age and cause
Proportion of population subjected to (a) physical violence, (b) psychological violence and/or (c) sexual violence in the previous 12 months
Proportion of population that feel safe walking alone around the area they live after dark

practice_links.evidence: 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28) and open dialogue through 'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26) directly reduce local conflict and build trust, thereby reducing violence.

sdg_targets.description: End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children

indicators.description: Proportion of children aged 1–17 years who experienced any physical punishment and/or psychological aggression by caregivers in the past month
Number of victims of human trafficking per 100,000 population, by sex, age and form of exploitation
Proportion of young women and men aged 18–29 years who experienced sexual violence by age 18

practice_links.evidence: While not a primary focus, 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28) can provide a channel for reporting and protecting vulnerable groups, including children, from violence, an indirect effect.

sdg_targets.short_name: Promote Rule of Law & Access to Justice
sdg_targets.description: Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all

indicators.description: Proportion of victims of (a) physical, (b) psychological and/or (c) sexual violence in the previous 12 months who reported their victimization to competent authorities or other officially recognized conflict resolution mechanisms
Unsentenced detainees as a proportion of overall prison population
Proportion of the population who have experienced a dispute in the past two years and who accessed a formal or informal dispute resolution mechanism, by type of mechanism

practice_links.evidence: LCE directly promotes access to justice by establishing 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28) as trusted, accessible channels for dispute resolution.

sdg_targets.description: By 2030, significantly reduce illicit financial and arms flows, strengthen the recovery and return of stolen assets and combat all forms of organized crime

Proportion of seized, found or surrendered arms whose illicit origin or context has been traced or established by a competent authority in line with international instruments

sdg_targets.description: Substantially reduce corruption and bribery in all their forms

indicators.description: Proportion of persons who had at least one contact with a public official and who paid a bribe to a public official, or were asked for a bribe by those public officials, during the previous 12 months

Proportion of businesses that had at least one contact with a public official and that paid a bribe to a public official, or were asked for a bribe by those public officials during the previous 12 months

practice_links.evidence: Transparent processes like 'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26) and 'Transparency & Communication' (ac29), combined with 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28), directly reduce opportunities for corruption and bribery.

sdg_targets.description: Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels

indicators.description: Primary government expenditures as a proportion of original approved budget, by sector (or by budget codes or similar)
Proportion of population satisfied with their last experience of public services

practice_links.evidence: By providing feedback loops through 'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26) and 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28), LCE directly improves the responsiveness of public services, increasing satisfaction.

concern_links.evidence: This target for 'effective, accountable and transparent institutions' is a direct match.
Compliance requires transparent and accountable institutions to set and enforce regulations.
Effective and accountable institutions are a prerequisite for contract enforcement and payment security.

sdg_targets.description: Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels

indicators.description: Proportions of positions in national and local institutions, including (a) the legislatures; (b) the public service; and (c) the judiciary, compared to national distributions, by sex, age, persons with disabilities and population groups
Proportion of population who believe decision-making is inclusive and responsive, by sex, age, disability and population group

practice_links.evidence: The entire practice, especially 'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26), 'Stakeholder Capacity-Building' (ac27), and 'Continuous Consent' (ac30), is designed to ensure responsive, inclusive, and representative decision-making.

concern_links.evidence: Inclusive and participatory decision-making is the mechanism for ensuring benefits are shared equitably.
Responsive and inclusive decision-making is a key outcome of good governance.

sdg_targets.description: Broaden and strengthen the participation of developing countries in the institutions of global governance

indicators.description: Proportion of members and voting rights of developing countries in international organizations

sdg_targets.description: By 2030, provide legal identity for all, including birth registration

indicators.description: Proportion of children under 5 years of age whose births have been registered with a civil authority, by age

sdg_targets.description: Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements

practice_links.evidence: The core actions of 'Transparency & Communication' (ac29) and ensuring 'Continuous Consent' (ac30) are direct methods of ensuring public access to information.

concern_links.evidence: Protecting fundamental freedoms is a core aspect of human rights.
Public access to information is a cornerstone of transparency.
Ensuring public access to information directly enables academic research and collaboration.

sdg_targets.description: Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime

indicators.description: Existence of independent national human rights institutions in compliance with the Paris Principles

sdg_targets.description: Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development

indicators.description: Proportion of population reporting having personally felt discriminated against or harassed in the previous 12 months on the basis of a ground of discrimination prohibited under international human rights law

practice_links.evidence: Inclusive 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28) and open engagement through 'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26) directly reduce discrimination and increase the reporting and resolution of such cases.

practices.name: Economic Impact Management
practices.description: Aims to ensure positive economic contributions to local communities through employment and procurement, while proactively mitigating the negative impacts of non-local workforce models.
practices.remark: Key challenges include building local workforce capacity, which requires significant investment, and ensuring the equitable distribution of financial benefits, which can be hindered by governance issues.

target_links.evidence: Actions like 'Direct Employment' (ac2), 'Local Procurement' (ac1), and 'Benefit-Sharing Mechanisms' (ac5) directly provide income and economic resources, contributing to the eradication of extreme poverty.
target_links.math_model: Economic model linking jobs created and local spend to poverty reduction rates.

target_links.evidence: Through 'Direct Employment' (ac2), 'Local Procurement' (ac1), and gender-responsive 'Workforce Training & Capacity Building' (ac3), this practice directly helps reduce the proportion of people living in poverty.
target_links.math_model: Model linking employment and skills programs to household income levels.

target_links.evidence: 'Benefit-Sharing Mechanisms' (ac5) can be designed to fund local social protection schemes, and proactive 'Mitigation of Negative Labor-Market Impacts' (ac6) provides a safety net for affected workers.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking funds allocated to social protection via benefit-sharing.

target_links.evidence: The Practice Action 'Physical Infrastructure & Essential Services' (ac4) directly ensures access to basic services, a key component of this target.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking number of people with new access to services due to company investment.

target_links.evidence: Investment in 'Physical Infrastructure & Essential Services' (ac4) can increase community resilience to shocks, though it is an indirect effect of the primary economic goal.
target_links.math_model: Correlation model between infrastructure quality and community resilience indices.

target_links.evidence: 'Direct Employment' (ac2), 'Local Procurement' (ac1), and 'Benefit-Sharing Mechanisms' (ac5) are explicitly designed to boost incomes for the local population, which often constitutes the bottom 40%.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking income growth for lowest quintile households in the area.

target_links.evidence: By providing 'Direct Employment' (ac2) and implementing 'Benefit-Sharing Mechanisms' (ac5), the practice promotes economic inclusion for all, irrespective of status.
target_links.math_model: Qualitative link, no direct quantitative model.

target_links.evidence: While LCE is the primary driver, fair and inclusive 'Direct Employment' (ac2) and 'Workforce Training & Capacity Building' (ac3) practices indirectly reduce experiences of economic discrimination.
target_links.math_model: No direct model.

target_links.evidence: 'Direct Employment' (ac2) and fair wage policies directly increase the labor share of income within the local economy.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking local wage levels against national/regional averages.

target_links.evidence: The 'Mitigation of Negative Labor-Market Impacts' (ac6) action, which includes transition assistance and avoiding exploitative recruitment, directly addresses this target.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking outcomes for workers affected by FIFO or automation.

target_links.evidence: The action 'Physical Infrastructure & Essential Services' (ac4) often includes building or upgrading local schools, which directly supports primary and secondary education completion.
target_links.math_model: Model linking investment in schools to student enrollment and completion rates.

target_links.evidence: Increased family income from 'Direct Employment' (ac2) and investment in community infrastructure like daycare centers via 'Benefit-Sharing Mechanisms' (ac5) can increase participation in early childhood education.
target_links.math_model: Model linking household income to pre-primary education enrollment.

target_links.evidence: 'Workforce Training & Capacity Building' (ac3) is the primary driver for this, directly increasing participation rates in vocational and technical education.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking number of people completing vocational training programs.

target_links.evidence: The action 'Workforce Training & Capacity Building' (ac3) directly provides youth and adults with relevant technical and vocational skills for employment.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking skills acquisition and subsequent employment rates.

target_links.evidence: 'Workforce Training & Capacity Building' (ac3) that explicitly focuses on gender equality and other vulnerable groups directly helps to eliminate disparities in education.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking enrollment of vulnerable groups in training programs.

target_links.evidence: While not a primary focus, investments in 'Workforce Training & Capacity Building' (ac3) and general education via 'Physical Infrastructure & Essential Services' (ac4) indirectly contribute to raising adult literacy.
target_links.math_model: No direct model.

target_links.evidence: The Practice Action 'Physical Infrastructure & Essential Services' (ac4) directly involves the funding and construction of schools and the provision of basic services like water and electricity to them.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking investment in education facilities.

target_links.evidence: Community investments funded by 'Benefit-Sharing Mechanisms' (ac5) and direct support for 'Physical Infrastructure & Essential Services' (ac4) can include teacher training and incentives, boosting the supply of qualified educators.

target_links.math_model: Correlation model between household income and child labor rates.

practices.name: GHG Emissions Management
practices.description: Aims to reduce direct (Scope 1) and indirect (Scope 2 & 3) greenhouse gas emissions in line with climate science, contributing to the global transition to a low-carbon economy.
practices.remark: Requires substantial upfront capital for renewable energy projects and fleet electrification. Integrating new technologies can be operationally complex and dependent on local grid stability. Scope 3 data collection remains a challenge.

target_links.evidence: While primarily an air quality measure, Practice Action 'Conduct Air Quality Monitoring' (ac16) indirectly addresses urban environmental impact, which has a minor relation to GHG.
target_links.math_model: No direct model.

target_links.evidence: The overall goal of achieving sustainable management of resources aligns with reducing the GHG emissions intensity of extraction.
target_links.math_model: Model linking GHG per ton of ore to sustainable resource management score.

target_links.evidence: The entire 'Climate Change Mitigation' practice (p_ghg_mitigation) represents the integration of climate change measures into policies and planning.
target_links.math_model: Qualitative link, no direct quantitative model.

target_links.evidence: ocean acidification is directly driven by atmospheric CO₂; a core indicator of carbon uptake.
target_links.math_model: Stoichiometric model of CO2 dissolution and ocean pH change.

target_links.evidence: Practice Action 'Transition to Renewable Energy' (ac7) directly contributes to increasing the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix.
target_links.math_model: Model linking energy source (MWh) to % of total energy mix.

target_links.evidence: Practice Action 'Adopt Energy-Efficient Technologies' (ac8) directly contributes to doubling the global rate of improvement in energy efficiency.
target_links.math_model: Model linking technology upgrades to energy consumption per unit of production.

target_links.evidence: Practice Action 'Adopt Energy-Efficient Technologies' (ac8) indirectly helps decouple economic growth from environmental degradation by improving resource efficiency.
target_links.math_model: Correlation model between resource efficiency and GDP decoupling.

target_links.evidence: Practice Action 'Electrify Mobile Fleet' (ac9) and 'Upgrade Infrastructure & Retrofit Industries' are key methods for making industries more sustainable and adopting clean technologies.
target_links.math_model: Model of emissions reduction based on fleet electrification rate.

practices.name: Air Quality Management
practices.description: Aims to prevent and mitigate air pollution (e.g., SOx, NOx, Particulate Matter, heavy metals) from all mining activities to protect the health of workers and local communities, and to minimize impacts on ecosystems.
practices.remark: Presents significant operational challenges, especially managing dust from large-scale open-pit mines. Controlling toxic emissions (e.g., mercury from smelting) can require specialized and costly technology.

target_links.evidence: Air quality management primarily reduces the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities related to air quality.
target_links.math_model: Dispersion model linking emission sources to ambient air quality in urban areas.

target_links.evidence: This practice directly supports the environmentally sound management of chemicals and all wastes to significantly reduce their release to air.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking mass balance of chemicals and their release pathways.

target_links.evidence: The release of Sulfur Oxides (SOx) and Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) are known precursors to acid rain, which is a major contributor to ocean acidification. Practice Action 'Implement Specialized Emission Controls' (ac14) directly addresses this.
target_links.math_model: Atmospheric chemistry model linking SOx/NOx emissions to acid rain formation and subsequent ocean pH impact.

target_links.evidence: Clean air can benefit mountain vegetation, reduce acidification/ozone stress and help protect mountain ecosystems from air pollution impacts.
target_links.math_model: Model linking air pollutant concentrations to forest health indicators in mountain regions.

target_links.evidence: Mitigating air pollution indirectly contributes to reducing child mortality rates associated with respiratory illnesses.
target_links.math_model: Epidemiological model linking PM2.5 concentration to child respiratory mortality.

target_links.evidence: Reducing air pollution can indirectly help combat communicable diseases, particularly respiratory infections.
target_links.math_model: Correlation model between air quality index and incidence of respiratory infections.

target_links.evidence: Air pollution is a known contributor to non-communicable diseases (e.g., cardiovascular, respiratory), so control measures have a direct link to reducing NCD mortality.
target_links.math_model: Dose-response model linking pollutant exposure to NCD incidence.

target_links.evidence: reduction in air pollution leads to lower mortality from air pollution.
target_links.math_model: Model linking reduction in PM2.5/SOx/NOx to number of averted deaths.

target_links.evidence: Air emissions like NOx and SOx can contribute to water pollution through acid rain.
target_links.math_model: Atmospheric deposition model linking air emissions to water body acidification.

action_links.evidence: Air emissions are released during transportation.
Organizations utilize dust control measures to prevent or mitigate dust exposure for workers and communities, including ventilation systems, dust collectors, irrigation bars, dry fog, water cannons.
The extraction and smelting of non-ferrous metals can produce mercury gases and other toxic emissions.
Organizations utilize dust control measures such as bunds of trees.
Air quality surveys can be undertaken to assess the adequacy of controls.

practices.name: Biodiversity Management
practices.description: Aims to manage and mitigate the direct and indirect impacts of mining on all levels of biodiversity (ecosystems, species, genetics) by applying the mitigation hierarchy (avoid, minimize, restore, offset).
practices.remark: Impacts can be severe and extend beyond the mine site, including deforestation, habitat fragmentation, and pollution. The increasing demand for minerals drives activities into more ecologically sensitive areas, heightening risks.

action_links.evidence: Direct drivers of biodiversity loss influence biodiversity and ecosystem processes, leading to impacts such as degradation of ecosystems, habitat fragmentation, and animal mortality.

To limit and manage impacts on biodiversity, many mining organizations use the mitigation hierarchy tool to help inform their actions... The mitigation hierarchy follows avoidance, minimization, restoration, rehabilitation, and offset.

Mining activities may contribute to the direct drivers of biodiversity loss through land and sea use change... exploitation of natural resources... introduction of invasive alien species; and pollution.
Reporting these... ensures the organization provides sufficient information about its impacts in relation to the topic.

practices.name: Water and Effluents Management
practices.description: Aims to manage water as a shared resource by ensuring the efficiency of its operational use and mitigating the impacts of its discharge to protect human health, ecosystems, and the long-term viability of local water sources.
practices.remark: Impacts on water availability and quality are significant and can persist beyond mine closure. Operations in water-stressed regions intensify competition for resources and can exacerbate tensions with local communities.

target_links.evidence: Practice Action 'Improve Water Use Efficiency' (ac22) is a key component of achieving sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.
target_links.math_model: Model linking water withdrawal rates to overall natural resource accounting frameworks.

target_links.evidence: Managing effluents and water discharge is critical for the environmentally sound management of hazardous waste and chemicals to prevent their release to water.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking mass balance of chemical releases into water bodies.

target_links.evidence: Managing effluents and preventing contaminated runoff directly helps reduce marine pollution from land-based activities.
target_links.math_model: Hydrological model linking land-based runoff to coastal water pollution loads.

target_links.evidence: Responsible water management ensures the conservation and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems.
target_links.math_model: Model linking groundwater levels and surface water flows to ecosystem health.

target_links.evidence: Proper water management can play a role in combating desertification and restoring degraded land, particularly in water-scarce regions.
target_links.math_model: Model linking water availability to soil moisture and vegetation cover.

target_links.evidence: By managing water quality and preventing contamination, this practice helps reduce the spread of water-borne diseases.
target_links.math_model: Epidemiological model linking water quality parameters (e.g., fecal coliforms) to disease incidence.

target_links.evidence: Proper water management, including preventing contamination, directly contributes to reducing deaths from unsafe water and soil pollution.
target_links.math_model: Model linking contaminant concentrations in water to public health outcomes.

target_links.evidence: This practice directly supports achieving access to safe and affordable drinking water, often a key component of community development agreements.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking number of households with access to potable water as a function of investment.

target_links.evidence: Mining operations often support or develop local sanitation and hygiene facilities as part of their water management and community engagement strategies.
target_links.math_model: Model tracking number of people with access to improved sanitation facilities.

target_links.evidence: Practice Action 'Manage Water Discharge Quality' (ac23) is a core component aimed at improving water quality by treating wastewater.
target_links.math_model: Water quality model linking effluent treatment efficiency to receiving water body contaminant levels.

target_links.evidence: Practice Action 'Improve Water Use Efficiency' (ac22) directly addresses the goal of increasing efficiency and managing withdrawals.

target_links.evidence: Effective water management at a mine site is a key part of Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) at the local and catchment level.

target_links.evidence: By managing withdrawals and preventing pollution, this practice directly helps protect and restore water-related ecosystems.

action_links.evidence: Mining organizations can influence hydrology and have impacts on the livelihoods of local communities by altering groundwater levels, shifting river flow regimes...
The total volume of freshwater withdrawn for mining operations can also vary according to an organization's ability to substitute freshwater... and recycling infrastructure.

The impacts of mining activities on the quality of surface water, groundwater, and seawater can be due to water discharge and runoff, heavy metal contamination, spills, leaks or leaching of chemicals...
Acid mine drainage can be one of the most significant water impacts from metal mines...

In areas already facing water stress, mining operations can aggravate the problem by reducing water accessibility for other users and intensifying competition for water. These impacts can exacerbate tensions...

LCE directly promotes access to justice by establishing 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28) as trusted, accessible channels for dispute resolution.

Transparent processes like 'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26) and 'Transparency & Communication' (ac29), combined with 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28), directly reduce opportunities for corruption and bribery.

By providing feedback loops through 'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26) and 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28), LCE directly improves the responsiveness of public services, increasing satisfaction.

The entire practice, especially 'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26), 'Stakeholder Capacity-Building' (ac27), and 'Continuous Consent' (ac30), is designed to ensure responsive, inclusive, and representative decision-making.

Inclusive 'Effective Grievance Mechanisms' (ac28) and open engagement through 'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26) directly reduce discrimination and increase the reporting and resolution of such cases.

'Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment' (ac26) helps identify the health needs of marginalized women, improving the targeting of health interventions that reduce maternal mortality, though the effect is indirect.

action_links.evidence: An organization is expected to conduct community engagement to understand the vulnerabilities and priorities of local communities and how they may be affected by the organization’s activities.
Meaningful engagement also entails consultation with local communities before making decisions, including by acknowledging the power imbalance...
Organizations further address their negative impacts by establishing or participating in grievance mechanisms and other remediation processes tailored to community needs.
Meaningful engagement with local communities involves two-way communication that is transparent, proactive, responsive, and ongoing.
Meaningful engagement... is essential for obtaining and retaining a social license to operate.

practice_actions.name: Local Procurement
practice_actions.description: Prioritizing sourcing goods/services from local suppliers and small businesses.

practice_actions.name: Direct Employment
practice_actions.description: Hiring and maintaining local workforce across all skill levels.

practice_actions.name: Workforce Training & Capacity Building
practice_actions.description: Investing extensively in vocational skills, professional training, and leadership programs for locals, explicitly addressing gender equality and diversity.

practice_actions.name: Physical Infrastructure & Essential Services
practice_actions.description: Direct financing, construction, or upgrading of critical community infrastructure (roads, schools, health centers, water and sanitation, energy).

practice_actions.name: Benefit-Sharing Mechanisms
practice_actions.description: Implementing transparent and formal mechanisms explicitly designed for equitable sharing of financial gains (e.g., revenue sharing, equity ownership, royalty payments, community trust funds).

practice_actions.name: Mitigation of Negative Labor-Market Impacts
practice_actions.description: Proactive management of workforce changes caused by automation or "fly-in, fly-out" (FIFO) operations, including retraining programs, transition assistance, relocation support, and direct compensation for affected local workers.

practice_actions.name: Transition to Renewable Energy
practice_actions.description: Transitioning to renewable energy infrastructure (e.g., solar, wind power plants).

practice_actions.name: Adopt Energy-Efficient Technologies
practice_actions.description: Implementing new technologies and optimizing operational budgets to improve energy efficiency.

practice_actions.name: Electrify Mobile Fleet
practice_actions.description: Electrifying mining equipment and vehicle fleets.

practice_actions.name: Invest in Carbon Capture
practice_actions.description: Funding and implementing carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies.

practice_actions.name: Rehabilitate for Carbon Sequestration
practice_actions.description: Using post-closure rehabilitation efforts, such as reforestation, to capture CO2.

practice_actions.name: Optimize Transportation Routes
practice_actions.description: Designing and managing transportation routes and methods to minimize emissions and dust.

practice_actions.name: Implement Engineering Controls for Dust
practice_actions.description: Utilizing engineering controls such as ventilation systems, dust collectors, irrigation bars, and water cannons.

practice_actions.name: Implement Specialized Emission Controls
practice_actions.description: Using specialized technologies to mitigate emissions from smelting and other processing activities.

practice_actions.name: Use Vegetation for Dust Control
practice_actions.description: Planting vegetation (e.g., bunds of trees) for dust control.

practice_actions.name: Conduct Air Quality Monitoring
practice_actions.description: Performing regular air quality surveys and monitoring to assess and manage emissions.

practice_actions.name: Assess Biodiversity Impacts & Risks
practice_actions.description: Identifying and assessing the direct drivers of biodiversity loss, including impacts from land/sea use change, pollution, resource exploitation, and invasive species, particularly in or near ecologically sensitive areas.

practice_actions.name: Apply the Mitigation Hierarchy
practice_actions.description: Systematically applying the mitigation hierarchy to address identified impacts: prioritizing the avoidance of negative impacts, then minimizing them, followed by restoration and rehabilitation, and finally using offsets for residual impacts.

practice_actions.name: Manage Operational Drivers of Biodiversity Loss
practice_actions.description: Implementing specific operational programs and controls to manage the direct drivers of loss, such as pollution control systems, land clearance procedures, and invasive species management plans.

practice_actions.name: Monitor and Report Biodiversity State
practice_actions.description: Monitoring and reporting on the state of biodiversity and ecosystem services throughout the mine's life-cycle to evaluate the effectiveness of management actions and to ensure transparency.

practice_actions.name: Conduct Water Impact & Risk Assessments
practice_actions.description: Conducting assessments to identify and understand the potential impacts of mining operations on water quality, availability, and on local ecosystems and communities.

practice_actions.name: Improve Water Use Efficiency
practice_actions.description: Implementing technologies and operational processes to increase water-use efficiency, including the use of recycling and reuse technologies to reduce freshwater withdrawal.

practice_actions.name: Manage Water Discharge Quality
practice_actions.description: Implementing systems to manage and treat wastewater and effluents before discharge to ensure compliance with quality standards and to prevent contamination of surface and groundwater.

practice_actions.name: Prevent Acid Mine Drainage
practice_actions.description: Implementing specific actions and controls to prevent or mitigate the formation and release of acid mine drainage from rock and tailings.

practice_actions.name: Engage with Local Water Users
practice_actions.description: Engaging in collaborative approaches with local communities and other stakeholders to prevent and mitigate impacts on shared water resources, especially in water-stressed areas.

practice_actions.name: Participatory Needs & Impact Assessment
practice_actions.description: Conducting regular, inclusive consultations—with special attention to marginalized and vulnerable groups—to jointly identify and prioritize community needs and concerns, including formal community participation in environmental and social impact assessments (ESIAs).

practice_actions.name: Stakeholder Capacity-Building
practice_actions.description: Providing training and capacity-building for community representatives to enable their meaningful participation in decision-making.

practice_actions.name: Effective Grievance Mechanisms
practice_actions.description: Establishing trusted, accessible, and responsive grievance processes for the community.

practice_actions.name: Transparency & Communication
practice_actions.description: Maintaining clear communication channels, providing regular reporting, and establishing feedback loops with communities.

practice_actions.name: Continuous Consent
practice_actions.description: Implementing ongoing, proactive efforts to obtain and maintain community consent, rather than relying on single-instance approvals.

stakeholder_groups.name: Civil Society
stakeholder_groups.evidence: Azapagic 2004, GRI 14, Erzurumlu et al. 2014 and ...
stakeholder_groups.description: Groups representing public interests, community welfare, and non-commercial concerns.

stakeholders.name: Local Communities
stakeholders.definition: Individuals and families residing in the geographical area directly or indirectly affected by the mining project.
stakeholders.description: Main interests include health and safety, prevention of environmental pollution, local employment opportunities, and the company's active involvement in community life.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Employment. Specific Interest: '> Jobs & training (employment opportunities)'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Environmental pollution. Specific Interest: '> Clean, healthy and safe environment'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Social issues. Specific Interest: '> Respect for and preservation of cultural heritage'

Principle from Azapagic (2004): Company involvement in the community. Specific Interest: '> Equitable benefit‑sharing and meaningful engagement (fair distribution of wealth and participation in decision-making)'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Social issues. Specific Interest: '> Access to water > Land and resource rights'

stakeholders.name: Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) and Civil Society Organisations (CSOs)
stakeholders.definition: Independent, non-profit groups that advocate for specific environmental, social, or human rights issues.
stakeholders.description: Their primary concerns are centered on environmental protection and broader social issues, acting as public interest watchdogs.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): 'Green' products. Specific Interest: '> Responsible sourcing'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Environmental protection. Specific Interest: '> Protection of ecosystems & human rights'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Social issues. Specific Interest: '> Respect for human rights; > Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC) for indigenous peoples'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Social issues. Specific Interest: '> Governance, transparency and accountability; > Inclusive decision‑making.'

stakeholders.name: Women & Gender Groups1
stakeholders.definition: Advocacy groups focusing on the unique impacts of mining on women and promoting gender equality.
stakeholders.description: Their concerns are a subset of community and social issues, focusing on equitable access to employment and benefits, and mitigating specific health and social risks.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Employment. Specific Interest: '> Access to decent jobs and income'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Social issues. Specific Interest: '> Safe, discrimination‑free workplaces; > Mitigation of gender‑based violence and unequal burden of unpaid care.'

stakeholders.name: Population (Outside)
stakeholders.definition: People living outside the immediate project area who may be affected by downstream or transboundary impacts.
stakeholders.description: As part of the general public, their primary concerns relate to health and safety, environmental pollution, and the overall company image.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Health and safety, environmental pollution. No specific quote for this stakeholder.

stakeholders.name: Media
stakeholders.definition: Local, national, and international journalists, and news outlets that report on the mining project.
stakeholders.description: Their main interests lie in the company image and the reporting of significant events or potential scandals.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Company image. Specific Interest: '> Access to transparent and timely information > Corporate responsiveness to incidents > Honest, open communication'

stakeholders.name: Artisanal & Small-Scale Miners
stakeholders.definition: Individuals or small groups mining minerals with minimal technology, often in the informal sector.
stakeholders.description: As a distinct part of the local community, their primary interests are employment and livelihood, which can sometimes conflict with large-scale operations.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Price. Specific Interest: '> Fair market access and pricing'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Health and safety. Specific Interest: '> Safe working conditions.'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Employment. Specific Interest: '> Secure and legal access to mineral deposits'

stakeholder_groups.name: Project or Internal
stakeholder_groups.evidence: Azapagic 2004, GRI 14, Erzurumlu et al. 2014 and ...
stakeholder_groups.description: Individuals and entities directly involved in the planning and execution of the mining project.

stakeholders.name: Employees
stakeholders.definition: Individuals directly hired by the mining company to perform operational, technical, and administrative tasks.
stakeholders.description: Core interests are focused on occupational health and safety, job security, fair salary, and overall job satisfaction.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Employment. Specific Interest: '> Fair treatment (renumeration packages, benefits); > Equal opportunities in training and career development'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Health and safety. Specific Interest: '> Occupational health; and safety'

stakeholders.name: Trade unions
stakeholders.definition: Organizations that represent the collective interests of employees in negotiations with the mine operator.
stakeholders.description: Advocates for the collective rights of workers, focusing on health and safety, job security, and fair compensation and benefits.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Job security. Specific Interest: '> Fair treatment; > Equal opportunities; > Health and Safety'

stakeholders.name: Mine Operators
stakeholders.definition: The management and corporate entity responsible for the day-to-day and strategic operation of the mine.
stakeholders.description: Their interests encompass those of shareholders and investors, focusing on profitability and company image, while also managing employee, community, and government relations.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Risk. Specific Interest: '> Regulatory compliance and risk reduction'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Profitability. Specific Interest: '> Economic viability and productivity'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Company image. Specific Interest: '> Maintaining social license to operate > Strong community relations and workforce safety > Reputation and long-term sustainability'

stakeholders.name: Contractors
stakeholders.definition: Third-party companies hired to perform specific tasks such as construction, transportation, or specialized maintenance.
stakeholders.description: Their interests are similar to suppliers, focusing on securing long-term contracts and ensuring prompt payment for services rendered.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): 'Green' products. Specific Interest: '> environmental and social aspects of a company’s activities (consultant's interest)'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Long-term contracts. Specific Interest: '> Reliable contracts and throughput volumes.'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Profitability. Specific Interest: '> the economic performance of the company they are working for and their prospects for further contracts'

stakeholders.name: Suppliers
stakeholders.definition: Businesses that provide necessary goods and services, from heavy machinery to office supplies, for the mining operation.
stakeholders.description: Their primary interests are securing long-term contracts and receiving prompt payment for their goods and services.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Prompt payment. Specific Interest: '> whether their contracts will be paid in accordance with terms'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Profitability. Specific Interest: '> economic viability of the company they are supplying to'

stakeholders.name: Security Providers (Public & Private)
stakeholders.definition: Entities responsible for securing the mine site, assets, and personnel.
stakeholders.description: As a specialized type of employee or contractor, their key interest is health and safety within the context of their security role.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Health and safety. Specific Interest: '> Respect for human rights standards.'

stakeholder_groups.name: Market and Financial
stakeholder_groups.evidence: Azapagic 2004, GRI 14, Erzurumlu et al. and ...
stakeholder_groups.description: Stakeholders driven by economic and financial performance, investment, and market dynamics.

stakeholders.name: Customers
stakeholders.definition: Companies or entities that purchase the final mineral products from the mine.
stakeholders.description: Their main interests are product quality, competitive price, and product safety, with an increasing interest in environmentally friendly or 'green' products.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Product quality. Specific Interest: '> Stable, sustainably sourced raw materials)'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Price. Specific Interest: '> Purchase at competitive (minimum) cost'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Product safety. Specific Interest: '> Assurance of no environmental, health or safety risks in products'

stakeholders.name: Investors
stakeholders.definition: Individuals or institutions that provide capital to the mining project with the expectation of financial return.
stakeholders.description: Key interests include financial return on investment, long-term profitability, effective risk management, and the company's public image.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Risk. Specific Interest: '> Portfolio decarbonisation and ESG alignment'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Financial return, profitability. Specific Interest: '> Risk-adjusted financial returns'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Company image. Specific Interest: '> Supply-chain resilience > Transparency and accountability'

stakeholders.name: Sovereign Wealth Funds
stakeholders.definition: State-owned investment funds that may invest in the mining project or parent company.
stakeholders.description: As a type of investor, their concerns are financial return, profitability, and company image, often with a strong emphasis on low-risk profiles and long-term sustainability.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Financial return. Specific Interest: '> Long‑term financial returns; > Strategic access to future mineral supply chains.'

stakeholders.name: Development Finance Institutions (DFIs)
stakeholders.definition: Banks or financial institutions that provide capital for economic development projects.
stakeholders.description: As investors, they are concerned with financial return and risk, but also with the project's contribution to the local and national economy and compliance with social standards.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Risk. Specific Interest: '> Environmental and governance safeguards.'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Financial return. Specific Interest: '> Socio‑economic development impacts'

stakeholders.name: Commodity Traders & Metal Exchanges
stakeholders.definition: Entities that buy, sell, and trade the mined commodities on the global market.
stakeholders.description: As a type of customer, their interest is in the price and quality of the product, as well as the reliability of the supply chain.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Product safety. Specific Interest: '> Reliable provenance documentation.'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Price. Specific Interest: '> Arbitrage opportunities; > Liquidity and transparent pricing'

stakeholders.name: Shareholders
stakeholders.definition: Individuals and entities who own shares in the publicly-traded parent company of the mine.
stakeholders.description: Their main interests are financial return, profitability, and the overall company image, which influences share price.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Financial return, profitability. Specific Interest: '> Growing focus on socially-responsible investment (SRI)'

stakeholders.name: Creditors
stakeholders.definition: Banks and financial institutions that have loaned money to the project.
stakeholders.description: As a form of investor, their primary interest is the financial return and profitability of the company to ensure their loans are repaid.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Risk. Specific Interest: '> Screen borrowers on environmental & social performance > Competitive loan terms linked to ESG standards'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Financial return. Specific Interest: '> Minimise financial and reputational risk'

stakeholders.name: Insurers
stakeholders.definition: Companies that provide insurance coverage for various project risks.
stakeholders.description: As a type of investor, they are primarily concerned with risk, focusing on the company's health and safety performance and environmental management to minimize claims.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Risk. Specific Interest: '> potential env liabilities related to mine closure; > Limit exposure to catastrophic liabilities (e.g., tailings dam failures); > Stable political jurisdictions'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Risk. Specific Interest: '> Expectation of compliance with international safeguards.'

stakeholder_groups.name: Government and Regulatory
stakeholder_groups.evidence: Azapagic 2004, GRI 14, Erzurumlu et al. and ...
stakeholder_groups.description: Official bodies and organizations that set standards, enforce laws, and oversee the industry.

stakeholders.name: Local Authorities
stakeholders.definition: Municipal or regional government bodies responsible for public services and administration in the project area.
stakeholders.description: Interests include compliance with local legislation, tax revenues, the project's contribution to the local economy, and managing community health and environmental impacts.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Employment. Specific Interest: '> Local employment & business multipliers'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Compliance with legislation. Specific Interest: '> Environmental compliance'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Company involvement in the community. Specific Interest: '> Equitable sharing of mineral wealth'

stakeholders.name: Governments
stakeholders.definition: The national or federal government of the host country.
stakeholders.description: Primary interests are ensuring compliance with national legislation, collecting tax revenues, and maximizing the project's contribution to the national economy.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapazic (2004): Employment. Specific Interest: '> Safe Employment & industrialisation'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Compliance with legislation. Specific Interest: '> Environmental Compliance'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Contribution to national/local economy. Specific Interest: '> GDP contribution, royalties, and revenue and tax distribution'

stakeholders.name: International Initiatives / Standard Setters
stakeholders.definition: Global organizations that develop voluntary or mandatory standards for the mining industry.
stakeholders.description: Their goal is to improve the overall performance of the industry by influencing government regulations and company practices related to environmental and social issues.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Environmental protection, social issues. Specific Interest: '> Governance, transparency and ESG performance; > Alignment with international norms.'

stakeholders.name: Other Mine Operators
stakeholders.definition: Peer companies operating other mines, either in the same region or globally.
stakeholders.description: Their interests are in maintaining a positive overall company and industry image, which affects the social license to operate for all players.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Company image. Specific Interest: '> Benchmarking and best practice; > Market stability.'

stakeholders.name: Industry Associations
stakeholders.definition: Organizations that represent the collective interests of mining companies.
stakeholders.description: They focus on influencing government legislation and improving the overall company image of the mining sector.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Environmental protection. Specific Interest: '> Harmonised ESG standards'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Company image. Specific Interest: '> Reputation and licence to operate'

stakeholders.name: Academic & Research Institutions
stakeholders.definition: Universities and think tanks that study the mining industry and its impacts.
stakeholders.description: Their interest is in the company's transparency and image, providing data to the general public and NGOs to address environmental and social issues.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Company image. Specific Interest: '> Access to data and case studies; > Collaborative R&D opportunities; > Funding for applied research.'

stakeholders.name: Donors
stakeholders.definition: International aid agencies or philanthropic organizations that may fund related development or governance programs in the region.
stakeholders.description: Similar to NGOs, their interests are in seeing that mining contributes to, rather than undermines, broader environmental protection and social issue mitigation.

concern_links.evidence: Principle from Azapagic (2004): Compliance with legislation. Specific Interest: '> Facilitation and compliance with funding conditions.'
Principle from Azapagic (2004): Social issues. Specific Interest: '> Sustainable development outcomes; > Best practice implementation'
